Messages.Author: Furkan Davulcu
Messages.Content: Dear all,  Assignment 3 grades are now online. Thanks everyone for putting in all the effort again, we really like the progress you have made over the last weeks! I will give feedback to groups on supervised lab sessions if they want it. If you have some questions or confusion about your grade, just email/contact me.  On Wednesday, we are going to have our last demonstration session. Each group will have around 10 minutes. Please be ready with your robots (as instructed in the assignment) and only use the code you have submitted for grading. I will check your workspace at the time of demonstration with the submitted workspace.  We will follow this group ordering for demonstrations:  1. Red 2. Silver 3. Green 4. Orange 5. Pearlgreen 6. Plastic 7. Turquoise  Please make sure that you are ready to demonstrate your behaviors on your robots when you are the next group.  Best, Furkan

Messages.Author: Furkan Davulcu
Messages.Content: Dear all,  We are going to have our group presentations on July 1st and July 8th during our lecture time and class.  During the group presentations, each group has 12 minutes (+8 minutes for discussion) to present one (or more) aspect(s) of their solution, which they are especially proud of/shows a clever idea/is different from how other teams approached the problem/etc. It should be fun and interesting to see what you came up with.  Each team member should be involved in the presentation and present (roughly) the same amount. There will be 20 points awarded for the presentation.  Schedule for the presentations:  July 1st: 1. Silver 2. Orange 3. Plastic 4. Red  July 8th: 1. Turquoise 2. Lilac 3. Green 4. Pearlgreen  Best, Furkan

Messages.Author: Furkan Davulcu

Messages.Author: Furkan Davulcu
Messages.Content: Dear all,  Assignment 1 grades are now online. Thanks everyone for putting in all the effort, keep up the good work! I just want to note that not everyone in the same group will get the same grade. It still very much depends on the effort you have put into the assignment and your knowledge about the assignment content.  Please also try to focus about the issues we discussed during your demonstrations. Some general feedback: 1. For the groups who couldn't get the alignment done yet, please make sure to work on it and make your robots align in a cell at an acceptable performance. 2. Keep it simple, stupid (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KISS_principle) first! Try to get some behaviors running quickly! Only then you will be able to understand the full extend of what you need to do. 3. Read the documentation and try to understand the examples on different components of ROS that you are using. Having a deeper understanding of what's going on under the hood will make your lives easier! 4. Your reports should explain your approach you took in order to solve the problems in the assignment. Some reports were really good, however, some groups should put a little bit more effort into the report. I already communicated this to those groups during demonstrations. The idea is, we should be able to read your reports and understand what you are doing. It shouldn't include all the details of course, but it shouldn't also look like some random notes you took during development process!  If you still have some questions or confusion about your grade, just email/contact me.  Best, Furkan  P.S I think a lot of the Akin's laws of spacecraft design apply to robotics too, maybe have a look at them (https://spacecraft.ssl.umd.edu/akins_laws.html) but don't take them too literally for this course!

Each group will have around 8 minutes. See you tomorrow!  Best, Furkan

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Corrected version of the Maze map.txt

Messages.Author: Tobias Veselsky
Messages.Content: Hello everyone, First, a big thanks to Furkan for expanding, updating and especially building our lab's maze for the new assignment. Yesterday after the demonstrations, I spent time in the lab adding new features to our project and checking for bugs in previous code. Initially, the robot's localization functioned very reliably. However, towards the end of my lab session, I encountered a persistent localization issue. After a bit of testing I was even able to reproduce the issue reliably. Despite planning to leave the lab early, my curiosity led me to debug this issue. As this issue was reliably reproducible and our wall detection for each cell was spot on, I expected a fundamental issue in our localization implementation. This led me to increase our debug levels incrementally for a long long time, but with each debug level I still didn't find the Bug. Only late in the evening, after ramping up our debugging significantly, I was able to pinpoint the issue. Although Furkan thoroughly checked the new map file against the physical maze and even verified it with Team Green's visualizations and on first glance the map seemed accurate, creating such maps manually in a text file is obviously inherently susceptible to errors. The error involved a missing wall at the bottom of the maze. This wasn't immediately apparent since our robot didn’t attempt to exit the maze through the non-existent boundary as there is no neighboring cell it is allowed to enter, but it obviously disrupted our localization as it expected no wall there. As finding that issue took me way too much time and to ensure you don't need to spend time troubleshooting a non-existent code issue as well, I have updated the map file to include the missing wall. Here’s the corrected version for download: map.txt This might also be (maybe even more) interesting for you: Download Link Best regards, Tobias

Messages.Author: Furkan Davulcu
Messages.Content: Hi Tobias,  Thanks for finding and reporting the error in the file! :) I will update it accordingly.  Best, Furkan

Messages.Author: Joshua Carrapita
Messages.Content: Is there a lecture today as today is a public holiday? Tia Josh

Messages.Author: Furkan Davulcu

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Out of curiosity, why not Actions in assignment 2?

Messages.Author: Joshua Carrapita
Messages.Content: Why are we not using actions for assignment 2 as shown in the ros documentation, they seem like the more appropriate type for the task since we're not doing a "quick" calculation? Just curious, looking forward to the answer! Greetings Josh

Messages.Author: Furkan Davulcu
Messages.Content: Dear Josh,  Excellent question! First of all, the documentation you sent is for ROS2, not ROS1, however there is the comparable actionlib (http://wiki.ros.org/actionlib) in ROS1. You are right about services would be used for some quick calculations/requests. I missed out on this in our assignment because I was focusing on something else, sorry!  I agree that waiting for the whole plan execution to end in order to return the service call is not ideal. So, I would suggest this to everyone instead: You can immediately return the service call, however, you should play a short sound/song on the robot when the plan is not achievable (aka the robots would need to jump over the wall to be able to execute the plan). Similarly, when the robot finishes its execution of the plan, it should play another sound/song to report success!  Best, Furkan

Messages.Author: Joshua Carrapita
Messages.Content: Since we mentioned in the lecture that it's unnecessary for us to all implement matrix multiplication etc., are we allowed to use e.g. the Eigen library? Tia Josh

Messages.Author: Furkan Davulcu
Messages.Content: Yes, you can use Eigen.

Messages.Author: Alexander Schwind
Messages.Content: Can you please explain how to install this library?

Messages.Author: Julian Guillaume Böhm
Messages.Content: I found these instructions: https://gitlab.com/libeigen/eigen/-/blob/master/INSTALL

Messages.Author: Julian Guillaume Böhm
Messages.Content: When driving for over 32767mm, driver.py fails to encode the distance provided by iCreate into the 16-bit SensorPacket.distance field. Even though the iCreate spec may claim that distance is only a 16-bit integer, if we just change SensorPacket.distance to a 32-bit field, it provides values well outside the 16-bit range. Is it allowed to make this change in SensorPacket.msg for the assignments and the challenge? I know it is important to still handle overflows in sensor values, but this at least prevents driver.py from crashing entirely. Pictured: Modified SensorPacket.msg on the left, rostopic echo /sensorPacket output on the right.

Messages.Author: Furkan Davulcu
Messages.Content: I am going to update the create_fundamentals package after the first homework is done. Until that happens, you can use that fix to prevent the driver from crashing. Thanks for testing it out!

Messages.Author: Ulas Dilek
Messages.Content: Hey everyone, If you do not want to mess with setting up a dual-boot or face the performance effects of VirtualBox, you can use WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux) on your Windows machines. You can install an Ubuntu version and start using it from the command line (it is also supported by all major IDEs so you can use it while developing your projects). After you setup WSL on your PC, you need to install the desired Ubuntu version from the Windows Store and configure your environment. It is quite easy to work on it after you set it up. The only important thing is that you install Ubuntu version 20.04 since ROS Noetic cannot be installed on newer versions. At least I could not make it work with the most recent Ubuntu version anyway :/ Disclaimer: I am a student and I do not know if the usage of WSL needs to be approved by the teaching body (this forum entry is also an implicit question). So, take my advice with a grain of salt :D
